oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Failure of a novel surface polysaccharide targeting vaccine to prevent Tritrichomonas foetus infection in beef cattle
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hairgrove, T. B.
Thompson, J. A.
Rocha, J. N.
Vinacur, M.
Roberts, C.
Pier, G. B.
Cywes-Bentley, C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Tritrichomonas foetus
T. foetus
bovine trichomoniasis
immunization
pregnant cows
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tritrichomonas foetus (T. foetus) is the causative agent of bovine trichomoniasis that has a major impact on production costs for beef cattle farmers. Immunization strategies to effectively protect against T. foetus are a high priority. T. foetus expresses a surface polysaccharide, beta 1-6 poly-Nacetyl glucosamine (PNAG). A PNAG-specific vaccine has demonstrated protection in pigs and horses. This study attempted to protect pregnant cows from an experimental T. foetus infection by prior vaccination with a PNAG-specific vaccine.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2020; 368
